Violation_Type: Membership in an organization likely to engage in violent acts
Legal_Issue: Whether s. 19(1)(g) of the Immigration Act violates principles of fundamental justice, administrative law, or Charter rights
Governing_Law: Section 7 and Section 2(d) of the Charter
Application_Facts: Mr. Al Yamani, a Palestinian permanent resident, was suspected of being a member of the PFLP, an organization considered likely to commit violent acts; he engaged in activities supporting PFLP causes
Decision_Outcome: SIRC's process did not violate fundamental justice; however, s. 19(1)(g) was found to infringe freedom of association under s. 2(d) of the Charter and was not justified under s. 1
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of SIRC's decision and Governor General-in-Council's deportation order
Court_Ruling: s. 19(1)(g) is unconstitutional for violating freedom of association; SIRC report and deportation orders quashed
Defendant_Behavior: Alleged support for and membership in PFLP, including activities promoting its causes
Grounds_for_Claim: Reasonable grounds to believe individual is a member of an organization likely to engage in violence endangering lives or safety in Canada
Legal_Standard: Proportionality and justification under s. 1 of the Charter
Assessment_Factor: National security interests balanced with procedural fairness
Applicable_Legislation: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, ss. 2(d), 7, 1
Credibility_Assessment: Evidence of applicant's involvement with PFLP assessed as sufficient by SIRC but subject to Charter scrutiny
Application_Basis: Membership in an organization deemed likely to engage in violent acts
Relief_Sought: Quashing of SIRC report and deportation order
Governing_Rule: A person may be excluded if there are reasonable grounds to believe they will engage in violence or belong to a violent organization
Outcome: s. 19(1)(g) declared invalid; SIRC decision and deportation orders set aside
Harm_Assessment: Potential threat to public safety and national security
Cause_Description: Government suspicion that Mr. Al Yamani posed a security risk due to alleged PFLP membership
Evidence_Handling: Reviewed by SIRC and subject to judicial scrutiny for fairness and Charter compliance
Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 2(d) of the Charter â€“ Freedom of Association
Residency_Compliance: Permanent resident status affected by security certification
Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of SIRC and Governor General-in-Council under immigration and security law
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence supported belief in organizational membership but raised Charter concerns
Decision_Rationale: While procedures were fair, the statutory provision unjustifiably infringed Charter-protected freedom of association
